content:
The psyTeachR team at the University of Glasgow School of Psychology has successfully made the transition to teaching reporducible research using R across all undergraduate and postgraduate levels. Our curriculum now emphasizes essential ‘data science’ graduate skills that have been overlooked in traditional approaches to teaching, including programming skills, data visualisation, data wrangling and reproducible reports. Students learn about probability and inference through data simulation as well as by working with real datasets.
This website contains our open materials for teaching reproducible research.
summary: The psyTeachR team at the University of Glasgow School of Psychology has successfully made the transition to teaching reporducible research using R across all undergraduate and postgraduate levels. Our curriculum now emphasizes essential ‘data science’ graduate skills that have been overlooked in traditional approaches to teaching, including programming skills, data visualisation, data wrangling and reproducible reports. Students learn about probability and inference through data simulation as well as by working with real datasets.
A quick start guide for the specific bookdown templates we're using at UofG Psychology, plus a style guide and inclusion guidelines for open science materials.
title: Course Book Template

summary: Coding is a skill that can be picked up by people from all backgrounds, for any kind of data. Everyone can be a data scientist! Coding skills provide tools to enhance communicating your data and ideas to a wide range of audiences and disciplines. If you’ve ever wanted to learn how to make your own website or to visualise your data in a way that is engaging and rigorous, coding is for you. In addition, showcasing your findings in new ways may help you look at your data from a different perspective and lead to a deeper understanding of data.
title: Hack Your Data Beautiful

content:
Crowdsourcing Psychological Science Benedict Jones Crowdsourcing presents a solution to problems of low power and lack of diversity in research samples that often undermine conclusions from psychological research. I will focus on my lab’s experience conducting a preregistered study through the Psychological Science Accelerator, a globally distributed network of >350 laboratories from >45 countries.
Do Psychological Effects Vary across Sample and Setting? Findings from Many Labs 2 Richard Klein This talk presents results from Many Labs 2, a recent large-scale project in which 28 psychological effects were replicated across 125 samples from 36 countries (N = 15,305). This talk will emphasize whether replication effect size varies based on the specific sample or setting of data collection.
Teaching Open Science Niamh Stack To address recent concerns about the reliability of psychological findings, some have emphasized the need to improve training at a grassroots level (cf. Button et al., 2016). This talk discusses how we can answer this call by supporting undergraduates in becoming more intelligent ‘consumers of science’ (Diener & Biwas-Diener, 2016).
Writing Reproducible Manuscripts Lisa DeBruine Perhaps half of published psychology papers contain at least one inconsistent statistic (e.g., Nuijten et al, 2016). I will discuss methods for reproducible manuscripts that reduce transcription errors and act as self-documentation of data and analysis. These techniques promote open science and make it easier to meet new journal requirements.
summary: Open science reforms may be seen as added barriers to research. This symposium emphasizes the opposite: ways to utilize these reforms to accelerate research programs. Included talks will discuss results from large-scale replication projects ('Many Labs 2'), crowdsourcing science, reproducible and automatic results reporting, and how to teach open science.
title: Open Science Toolbox: Leveraging Methodological Reforms to Accelerate Research

summary: Tutorial materials for creating a shiny app that records questionnaire input.
title: Data Input in R/Shiny

summary: Our teaching team has successfully made the transition to teaching R across all undergraduate and postgraduate levels, and we are organising this workshop in order to share experiences, insights, and teaching materials with academic staff from other institutions.
title: Teaching Reproducible Data Analysis in R

summary: Materials for the University of Glasgow Institute of Neuroscience and Psychology’s Academic Websites class in the MSc Professional Skills course. It will show you how to create a simple academic website using GitHub and RStudio.
title: Academic Webpages with RMarkdown and GitHub/GitLab

summary: MSc course materials providing an overview of skills needed for reproducible research and open science using the statistical programming language R, including data visualisation, data tidying and wrangling, archiving, iteration and functions, probability and data simulations, general linear models, and reproducible workflows.
title: Data Skills for Reproducible Science
